Posts.Content: Aug 5, 2011 12:53PM lifegoeson wrote: Weighing in late on this...but my lymphedema is definitely activated by high heat and especially humidity.  My arms swell if I sit in the sun.
Posts.Title: Can very hot weather bring on lymphedema? Alicia moogie

Posts.Content: Dec 29, 2009 04:39PM lifegoeson wrote: Oh I'm so sorry to hear this.  I just found the thread and was going to post my experience with the "luxury suite" hospital rooms, and now I hear that due to insurance, you might not have the surgery next month.  I hope that you either find another surgeon or BIMC ends up accepting your health insurance.  Hopefully that will sort itself out. In any event, I paid the $$ for the luxury hospital room at North Shore Univ Hospital in Manhasset.  It was NOT worth it at all.  It was a beautiful room, but so what.  I was pretty out of it the whole time, and so I couldn't enjoy the huge flat screen TV, etc. The nursing care was absolutely horrilble in my "private luxury wing" of the hospital.  That was what really bothered me.  In the end, I got a robe and slippers to keep.  Don't pay the extra money, it's not worth it.  Again, I hope you get to have your surgery next month.
Posts.Title: Luxury suite anyone? NancyD cakeisgreat

Posts.Content: Jun 24, 2009 04:59PM lifegoeson wrote: I had lat flap surgery on March 10 and I also had numbness in my back.  My PS said it was normal and that it would take time for the feeling to come back. Now at 3 months out, a lot of feeling has returned but I still do have some numbness in the low back. It takes time and it wasn't until 2 months out that the feeling even started to return.  Hope that helps.  I'd be interested to hear what your doctor says about it, please let us know.
Posts.Title: numbness in my back ginamaria ginamaria

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2009 09:21AM lifegoeson wrote: I didn't have a pull at the cleavage, it was more in the armpit area. The fills for me were no big deal and not painful at all.  First the doctor finds the port in the expander with a magnet device that's sort of like a stud-finder.  Then they will clean the area, and then inject the saline.  You won't feel the needle at all.  My doctor filled my expanders to 200ccs at the surgery, then waited a couple of weeks.  The fills were then only 50cc at a time.  That's only like a shot glass full, not much at all, so you shouldn't feel it.  If he adds more at once, you may feel it.  I saw a noticeable difference in size at each fill though, which was great. Good luck!
Posts.Title: numbness in my back ginamaria ginamaria

Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2009 08:21PM lifegoeson wrote: Stretching exercises really helped me get my range of motion back after my surgery.  I haven't done them in a while, maybe I should start again, it can't hurt to keep things moving.
Posts.Title: numbness in my back ginamaria ginamaria

Posts.Content: Jun 24, 2009 10:55PM lifegoeson wrote: Mine was very large, and grew really quickly and the breast was reddened where the lump was.  I also had bloody discharge from my nipple.  The whole breast hurt.  I've had lots of lumps before and they were all benign but I knew this was different. My grandmother had breast cancer with a radical mastectomy years ago, and lived to be 100.  My 2 aunts on my mother's side died of BC.  My cousin had BC and a mastectomy 2 years ago and is doing well.  My mother had melanoma and is doing well.  Another cousin died of lymphoma, and my uncle died from metastatic CA (not sure of the origin).  We've got some CA genes in the family but I'm hoping to beat my grandmother's 100 years.
Posts.Title: WHAT did YOUR lump FEEL like? gscott MomOfTeenGirl01

Posts.Content: May 11, 2009 10:57PM lifegoeson wrote: I had a bilateral mastectomy with LD flaps and TEs on 3/10.  I had a sentinel node biopsy and my surgeon told me in the recovery room that the preliminary finding was that the nodes were negative, but of course we had to wait for the final report.  I got the final report about a week later, confirmed that the nodes were negative.  I wasn't able to use my arms for a while, because of the LD muscle being removed.  I was under anesthesia for 13 hours and that took its toll too.  I think I was out of if for the first couple of days.  The nurse helped me shower in the hospital, and I was able to shower by myself when I came home.  My doctor said I could shower even with the drains.  I got a shower seat and I was able to shower with the handheld shower head.
Posts.Title: Questions about After Bilateral Mastectomy hlya lifegoeson

Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2009 10:00AM lifegoeson wrote: Thank you for posting that link.  Very interesting article, and I agree, the tendency to place anyone who doesn't test "BRCA positive" into the "normal risk" category, even if they have a very strong family history, is troubling.  The article suggests MRI for such women.  My sister, who has not had BRCA testing, is now getting yearly MRI screening for BC. On the plus side, it does say that while there is an increased risk of BC in such women there is no evidence of increased risk of ovarian cancer, which is good news indeed.
Posts.Title: BRCA testing came back negative! lifegoeson Mutd

Posts.Content: Jul 1, 2009 10:33PM lifegoeson wrote: Thank you Mouser and good luck renee!!
Posts.Title: BRCA testing came back negative! lifegoeson Mutd

Posts.Content: lifegoeson wrote: I'm breathing a huge sigh of relief here.  I  just got the results and the oncologist said the test came back "normal."  This was a message left on my voicemail, so there was no other explanation and I will call tomorrow for details but it sounds good! I was tested because I have a really strong family history - maternal grandmother with breast cancer, 2 maternal aunts with BC, first cousin (mothers side also) with BC, mother had melanoma, paternal grandmother stomach cancer, paternal uncle cancer (I don't know where and he's deceased), uncle on my dad's side died of non-hodgins lymphoma.  That's a lot of cancer, and a lot of BC.   Nobody else was tested but me.   Is this a trustworthy "real" negative or an uninformative negative? In any event, they didn't find the mutations they tested for, and now my ovaries get to stay where they are, which is good news indeed.  I would have had the ovaries and fallopian tubes removed if it had come back positive.   Dx 1/29/2009, DCIS, Grade 2, 0/2 nodes, ER+/PR- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: BRCA testing came back negative! lifegoeson Mutd

Posts.Content: Jul 4, 2009 08:12PM lifegoeson wrote: Hi Lisa, and thanks - that's basically what I got from reading about it.  But at this point, since I've already had a bilateral mastectomy, there's not much to be done from a practical standpoint anyway.  If it had tested BRCA positive I would have had my ovaries out, but with a negative, even an "uninformed negative," that is not necessary.  And on another subject - we Long Islanders finally got a nice weather weekend!
Posts.Title: BRCA testing came back negative! lifegoeson Mutd
